website_summaries.verdict: Great value for five grow bags. Breathable fabric gives you healthier plants.
pros: Available in multiple sizes, ranging from 1 to 30 gallons, so you have all the versatility you could need
Uses a landscaping fabric for the grow bags, which provides toughness and minimal weight
Has handles to make the bags easier to move
cons: Bag sizes tend to run a little small
Mold may grow on outside of bag

customer_reviews.title: Ok so I do a lot gardening. The grow ...
customer_reviews.text: Ok so I do a lot gardening. The grow bags work. This will be my second season using various sizes. A little background. I am an urban gardener living in the Mid West. . My yard is a large concrete patio about 40x20. The bags come in enough sizes to grow virtually every vegetable.
customer_reviews.author: Kevin

customer_reviews.title: Four Stars
customer_reviews.text: The material feels very strong. However smaller than described. Ill ad pictures of my 5g. And 3g.
customer_reviews.author: Sancho

customer_reviews.title: ... hesitant to purchase because I've never strayed far from smart pots, the price was the deciding factor
customer_reviews.text: I was hesitant to purchase because I've never strayed far from smart pots, the price was the deciding factor. I will never purchase smart pots again! Love these things.
customer_reviews.author: FlyLow

customer_reviews.title: Working as advertised
customer_reviews.text: So far I love my pots. I am not allowed to have an actual garden where I live so I bought two sets of the pots and my plants are doing well. I have tomatoes, peppers, eggplant, basil, squash, and zucchini. The plants are growing well, and I really like the fact that since I am trying to sell my house, if I end up moving I can take my little garden with me!!
customer_reviews.author: D in MI

customer_reviews.title: Great Value
customer_reviews.text: Work perfect and as intended. Good construction too, not one rip. They are cheap enough to be disposable, but definitely can be reused. Great value.
customer_reviews.author: Cody Smith

customer_reviews.title: Perfect solution for limited space
customer_reviews.text: Since we moved into a townhouse in the USA, we have very little ground space to grow anymore and our back deck is surrounded by trees so not much light. This left us with limited space on/around the front porch. I have started squash, cucumbers and potatoes in them. I am very lucky to have a lenient HOA that loves plants! These bags are perfect! I'm currently using 3 and will use 2 more this week for other plants.
customer_reviews.author: MadamTM

customer_reviews.title: Way too small
customer_reviews.text: These things are way smaller than advertised. If you’re going to buy them, make sure to get bigger ones than you need. Thank me later.
customer_reviews.author: Josh Butcher

customer_reviews.title: Sturdy, well-made, worth the couple extra dollars
customer_reviews.text: Of the 7-gallon grow bags bought here, these have been outstanding. The cloth is not flimsy and the handles are sewn on very well. I will gladly pay a couple dollars more for these having paid a couple dollars less for a different brand recently and learning the difference in quality. Using these for sweet potatoes and dwarf bananas. The stiffness of the handles makes a huge difference when hauling the bags around especially once full of soil and plants.
customer_reviews.author: Opinionated Normal Person

customer_reviews.title: I bought the 5 gallon bags and they didn't seem ...
customer_reviews.text: I bought the 5 gallon bags and they didn't seem big enough so I bought the 7 gallon bags. Here's a picture of the 7 gallon bags with a 5 gallon bucket.
customer_reviews.author: PatC

customer_reviews.title: 15-gal are true to size, do not run small
customer_reviews.text: Have been wanting some fabric pots for a while now but the price of smartpots always held me back. After reading some reviews of them running small (specifically a 5 gallon bucket being larger than tge 7-gallon fabric pot) I decided to get some 15-gallon ones rather than the 10-gallon ones i initially wanted (to be safe, since I will be transplanting from 3-gallon plastic bags). I used a standard 5-gallon bucket filled to the top as a measuring device, and my 15-gallon ones will hold right around 14 gallons, and I'm betting another gallon will fit once watered and settled. I'll say these are true to size, and will likely be ordering some 10-gallon ones in the near future.
customer_reviews.author: Michael Johnson

customer_reviews.title: This is perfect for us because we rent the home we live ...
customer_reviews.text: I bought two sets a couple of weeks ago. Wasn't quite sure about them at first but I was surprised by their sturdiness. The plants are thriving in them. We planted tomatoes, cucumbers, zucchini, and squash. I'm about to buy a few more sets. This is perfect for us because we rent the home we live in so we can't make gardens or make any changes to the landscaping. The pots allow us to move them around as needed for different amounts of sunlight, poor weather, etc.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great product!
customer_reviews.text: Grew veggies this summer on the deck for us, not the deer! Holding up well. Love the cinch tops, they helped maintain moisture. But, wow, are the 10 gal bags heavy when filled. Be careful or get help if you have to move them. Bumper crop for my first garden: Ass't Cherry Tom's, Ashley Cucs, Summer Squash: 7 gal Sweet Lemon Peppers, Zucchini, Maragolds 'n Salvia to detract bugs/attract bees: 10 gal. So many cuc salads 'n sandwiches, and we'll have pickles most of the winter! All varieties were suitable for containers. A lot of fun!
customer_reviews.author: The Gift Lady

customer_reviews.title: DO NOT ORDER THESE BAGS!
customer_reviews.text: I just received my order and it only contained 1 bag and an invoice that indicated 1 bag. The item clearly states that it is for a five pack. The size of the bag appears smaller than 7 gallons as well. Very disappointed in this product. The product is shipped from China.
customer_reviews.author: CAS

customer_reviews.title: Wrong size and shorted 4 planters.
customer_reviews.text: Did not receive the correct quantity, ordered a 5 pack, received only a single fabric pot. As a bonus it was not even the correct size, it couldn't have been any larger than 3 gallons, not the 7 gallons that was advertised.
customer_reviews.author: HJLII

customer_reviews.title: It look a lot smaller than a 7 gal more like a 5 gal or less
customer_reviews.text: I am not sure if this is actually a 7 gal (it says so on the tag). It look a lot smaller than a 7 gal more like a 5 gal or less.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Wrong size shipped
customer_reviews.text: Back in February I ordered some 10 gallon bags thinking I'd be all set for spring planting. Well this week when I open and to use the bags they look very big and not the 10 gallon size I wanted. What I got was a 25 gallon size. Now since I got these in February I can't return them anymore and I am stuck with these. If you look at the attached picture you will see that a new tag was placed over the original tag saying these were suppose to be 10 gallon bags but guess what they were not. I wish these companies would get their inventory straighten out. Now I'm stuck.
customer_reviews.author: Fred

customer_reviews.title: Nice sturdy bags
customer_reviews.text: Nice sturdy bags, handles on the 7 gal bag had no problem holding up under the weight of a full bag. I'm using these bags to try and stop from introducing bacteria or diseased soil. I am putting them on a hand made square frame made of 2 x 4 a little bigger then the bag and covering with a wire mesh strong enough to support the weight, this way the bags can have good drainage and air prune better then being on a hard flat surface.
customer_reviews.author: Jim R

customer_reviews.title: 0 stars if I could. This product is a ...
customer_reviews.text: 0 stars if I could. This product is a scam. When you look at the bags and see the tag they are #7 bags 260g. I use nothing but 7 gallon bags and these are no bigger than 5 gallon probably a little smaller. Don’t buy scammers.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: My plants died
customer_reviews.text: I bought these to add to my hard plastic containers. I bought 6 plants, 4 tomatoes and 2 peppers, and mixed and matched between these planters and my plastic ones. All the plants in these planters died, while all the ones in the plastic ones thrived. Everything else was the same, the dirt, compost, light exposure and water. I am led to believe these planters are terrible and should not be bought or used.
customer_reviews.author: Alexa Quinn

customer_reviews.title: Great!
customer_reviews.text: These things are terrific! Bought the 20 gal specifically for tomato plants.Plenty deep enough to grow and to stake. Planted two banana pepper plants in one and strawberries in another. Filled with garden soil and potting mix about 3 inches from the top. Seems all the plants are doing well so far. Handles on the sides are very sturdy and support the weight very well if they need moved. Seem to drain well also. If you don't have room in a.yard to plant or just don't like to dig or weed... like me... these bags are the answer.
customer_reviews.author: crazylegs5651

customer_reviews.title: So far so good. Strong material but yet water permeable and the ...
customer_reviews.text: So far so good. Strong material but yet water permeable and the handles make them easy to move. I bought them initially for cucumbers so I could grow them vertically (because they like to take over) but then also planted some Brussels sprouts. I just ordered another set so I can separate the cucumbers.
customer_reviews.author: Eveblack

customer_reviews.title: Much better than the plastic pots.
customer_reviews.text: I can't speak to the longevity of these bags because I just planted seedlings in them for the first time. But they seem to be well made. And I was very surprised to see that they seem to hold the moisture much better for the plants. Granted I always put about 3 inches of coconut coir in the bottom of all my pots. But even still, they do hold moisture better than plastic pots. And the plants do not get root bound as they do in the plastic pots. "Air pruning" is the term I've heard used. You can look that up on Youtube.
customer_reviews.author: Traveler1226

customer_reviews.title: The Perfect "POT"
customer_reviews.text: The perfect "pot" for veggies and/or flowers. I move around from place to place following the sun, turn it around for the sun to get to the other side. Heavy canvas material "breathes" and no need for holes in the bottom. I don't believe these are 7 gallon, maybe 5 gallons. They are much smaller than I had pictured, however, I planted 2 tomato plants in one, 4 cucumber plants in another and 5 plants of green beans in another and they have plenty of room to grow. I'm glad they are no bigger because I would not be able to pick up and move around.
customer_reviews.author: nutzatwerk

customer_reviews.title: They're not the size they say they are.
customer_reviews.text: They're definitely NOT the size they say they are. If you need a true 15 gallon container get the 20. That will be 15 gallons. I plastic lined one of the 15 gallon pots and filled it to the brim with 11 gallons of compost. Needless to say that's pretty far off. If you're in FL you need that space to contain moisture or you're just burning plants up. I didn't give it one star because I'm returning them for larger ones and don't know how they perform yet.
customer_reviews.author: B Wallace

customer_reviews.title: Better than pots
customer_reviews.text: They store nicer than a giant stack of pots, and are very good at controlling moist soils. There are many plants that require well draining soil, and these would work very well for those. We used them to dig out plants when we moved, and they did a great job of holding dirt in a shape with a plant inside while being transported 70 miles. I'm going to get some of the bigger ones for our tomatoes next year. A cheap, nice alternative to buying pots for things you don't have out all year. I reckon you could wash these out too, they're super durable, stitched construction, and definitely a better option than nursery pots.
customer_reviews.author: Patrick P.

customer_reviews.title: I feel like a farmer...
customer_reviews.text: Good strong handles, sturdy bags of good construction. You won't be disappointed if you have these bags. I looked this morning in the grow tent and noticed my first red cherry tomato among the green ones.
customer_reviews.author: UpRider

customer_reviews.title: Handy
customer_reviews.text: Handy for landscape planning which may span time and you want to give your purchases less stress in their smaller container. Can plant with the bag which eventually deteriorates. I replant decorative size house or patio plants that are out growing their planter can take my time trying them out in different locations with the bags.
customer_reviews.author: C. S.

customer_reviews.title: Great bags for tree plants
customer_reviews.text: I'm going to uses these to plant some bareroot trees and I didnt want to trim back the roots too much so I purchased these 15 gallon bags. I'm glad I didnt get one size up from the 15 gallon ones since these are pretty big. They are better to use than plastic pots bc they are much wider and not as tall as plastic pots so the roots can spread nicely. These also have nice handles on each side which is a big plus imo. It'll be much easier moving them around, I just hope it wont disrupt the roots too much since these are in bags and not a hard surface.
customer_reviews.author: MartyMar

customer_reviews.title: Very durable and well made - will update when plants growing
customer_reviews.text: They just arrived and look very good. They are sewn together in heavy duty thread with a chain-stitch that uses 4 individual threads (like the seams in denim jeans) and are made of a heavy 1/16 inch thick nonwoven felt-like material . The handles are stitched on with a square and an X so they should hold the weight of the bag/pot and dirt if I want to hang it up. All 5 looked very good. I'll try to remember to update this after I grow some plants in them.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Quality + handles
customer_reviews.text: The same or even better quality of the ones which cost 4 times the price, and they have included handles with the "name brand" one does not on its main product. Make the switch.
customer_reviews.author: Cass YoungTop Contributor: Gardening

customer_reviews.title: 2.75 gallons
customer_reviews.text: These are very well-made grow bags, but they are really only 2.75 gallons. I know this because I measured them. They will work for my purposes, so I am not returning them, but buyer beware.
customer_reviews.author: Johnnie

customer_reviews.title: Can't hold onto moisture
customer_reviews.text: I bought the 5 gallon and 2 gallon mostly for herbs, though I did try arugula and collards in them as well. Nothing grew. It wasn't my seeds because I also planted everything directly in the ground as well (to get a better idea of how well the bags work), and it's all growing well. I believe that because these are fabric bags they simply can't hold onto enough moisture for plants to grow in warm weather. I also bought the plastic grow bags for potatoes. Those are much better!
customer_reviews.author: JPSkotnik

customer_reviews.title: Lasted For Under A Month
customer_reviews.text: Mine lasted for just under a month before they gave out and had huge holes in them. It's unfortunate because I bought these before and they were fine. At least I'm still within my return window.
customer_reviews.author: Devin

customer_reviews.title: Loving my fabric pots!
customer_reviews.text: So far I'm loving them. They are a little difficult to full up with soil, but once the soil is in they keep shape well. This is something I would purchase again. I have yet to test the handles on the bags, but from what I saw they look nice and sturdy. I'm ready to see how my plants grow. In mine I put tomates, and broccoli. Updates soon to come!
customer_reviews.author: Kassie

customer_reviews.title: Best 2 gallon soft pots! 2 gallons+! Unlike many undersized, expensive soft pots! Just bought more!
customer_reviews.text: Excellent, 2 gallon soft pots! Actually a bit over 2 gallons! Usually just the opposite with others. Just bought another 5-pack! Durable, sturdy! Looks tops, like other high quality, similar products, but less expensive! Very satisfied! You should be, as well! Top of the line fabric pots. Much better than Hydrofarm, etc! I've tried most brands.. Will have to try their 3 gallon soft pots, though I found another excellent brand, great price. These 3 gallons may be better! Worth the try when I need more! Very nice, very high quality soft pots!
customer_reviews.author: Tim Turk

customer_reviews.title: I couldn't find flaws
customer_reviews.text: In my opinion, those are a must if you want to grow any plant which is susceptible to overwatering. What most people don't know is that fabric pots not only allow the so called "air pruning" (allowing plants to grow a wider root system), but they also allow oxygen to get back in the soil after watering from all the sides (preventing the roots from drowning due to overwatering) and they are much lighter than clay. And if I need to fill the pots with less soil than the maximum, I can just roll the edges over to reduce the height of the pot.
customer_reviews.author: Fabio

customer_reviews.title: These bags are surprisingly awesome!
customer_reviews.text: These bags are surprisingly awesome! We have several trees we have grown from seeds that we aren't ready to put into the ground yet, as we are in a rental property. These have been a perfect solution; giving them enough room to grow while still being transportable. We were concerned about using bags this large because we thought they would be difficult to move, but these have proved us wrong. The handles and material of the bags are surprisingly durable. These can be lifted by the handles, while completely full of soil and a 4-5 foot tall tree, and show no signs of ripping.
customer_reviews.author: ATXMomma

customer_reviews.title: Plants grew well used paper plate holder....No weeding ever!.
customer_reviews.text: Alowed roots to heat up and grow plants fast.....when summer came I was able to move plants to shade. They have stopped producing but this is the first year my plants have lasted this long alive.....hopefully will produce again in fall. I used a paper plate holder in the bottom to create a space as if in a hard bucket... They worked well I used mulch I created. Very Happy. No weeds will never grow in ground again.
customer_reviews.author: THOMAS kOZIOL

customer_reviews.title: Versatile
customer_reviews.text: Ok, second season of planting. We have a lot WILT problems here and the plastic containers seem to retain the the virus no matter what you do. So washed the bags off and left them in the sun all winter. Will see. Only had one handle that ripped out more like operators fault than product malfunction. What I really like is you can roll the sides down for the amount of soil you using in them can’t do that with plastic. The bags were used for tomatoes squash and zucchini last year and the same this year. Update to follow.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Smaller than the milk gallon.
customer_reviews.text: Size matters. The 1 gallon bags looked smaller than expected so I placed a gallon milk container inside the container. Will still use it because the material looks strong and similar to others I have. I currently use 5, 10 & 20 gallon bags.
customer_reviews.author: Naca

customer_reviews.title: Convenient and compact- buy it!
customer_reviews.text: Love the grow bags! So convenient and perfect for patio gardening. I bought the 2 gallon ones; will buy bigger ones the next time. The Serrano pepper plant needs a bigger one. The 2 gallon size was perfect for the cilantro plant.
customer_reviews.author: AS

customer_reviews.title: Great
customer_reviews.text: Been using for about a month now and they are great. They are fabric so keep in mind, water will seep out of them when watering. I've moved around several times since being filled with soul and plants and the handles are holding up nicely. I dont have them outside yet (they're an enclosed porch) as weather is still not cooperative but I believe they will do nicely based off other reviews on these kinds of bags. Love them so far.
customer_reviews.author: Crystal

customer_reviews.title: Great indoors or out!
customer_reviews.text: Solidly constructed and lightweight. Using them indoors with 17" dia. drip trays for container gardening. Also shared a couple with a friend for her outdoors tomato plants. Note that you need to be careful watering (or use a trash bag as a sleeve) as these are not at all waterproof - they aren't supposed to be. For plants needing good drainage (like tomatoes or citrus) they're a good option.
customer_reviews.author: C. Fisher

customer_reviews.title: Nice growing bag
customer_reviews.text: Growing smaller plants and will try stacking the 3 gallon bags filled with soil together for more depth as the plants develop and more bags on side if needed. Think small diameter stakes might help if need to move joined bags. Saw a review that roots will grow through bag into ground. Mine are inside on plates. Growing a plumeria tree cutting that is now rooted, Aztec Gold for indoor plant room. Plus two kinds of day lillies. Looking forward to trying tulips, Shasta daisies, Japanese chrysanthemum. Spider plant and gerbera daisy thriving very well.
customer_reviews.author: Meadow lark

customer_reviews.title: This WILL NOT HOLD A  GALLON!
customer_reviews.text: These bags are 3 quart size, nowhere near a gallon size. The sizes fluctuate from bag to bag, and the handles are different length on the same bag. I need to get some things planted, so I will use them, but this company definitely has some quality control issues. I will not use them again. (Wish I could attach a pick of my bags with one gallon jugs in them so you can visualize the size discrepancy.)
customer_reviews.author: Barbara Basel

customer_reviews.title: Best fabric containers I have used in my pond.
customer_reviews.text: I have been using fabric containers for years but usually the are considerably larger and that means more substrate and significant weight if moving them or removing them is necessary. I very much like the large size range of this product. It is more of a felt like material than a pellon. The best part is the looped handles on the top edges. These make it so much easier to lift or shift a plant. Very happy, ordering more.
customer_reviews.author: Tricia

customer_reviews.title: Better root systems with added air availability.
customer_reviews.text: It has been a year since i purchased these in 15 gallon size. i grew tomatoes in 4 of these and a papaya in the other and all did very well. required a little more water in summer but roots grown in these bags were superior to plastic pots. reused the tomatoe bags for winter collard greens, now bags are pretty beat up but compostable. i am ordering again for this year, easy to move and very tough.
customer_reviews.author: No Quarter

customer_reviews.title: Great as pot liners
customer_reviews.text: I'm new the the world of grow bags so I don't have anything to compare these one to, but I'm quite happy with my purchase. I'm using them as liners in bigger pots and it's great to have the handles on the grow bags to easily take the plants in and out of the larger pots. They work really great as liners. I don't think I'd like them as stand alone pots since they're aesthetically too basic, but if that's all you're looking for then you'd be happy with these. They of course leak water since they're just fabric, so don't expect them to be waterproof.
customer_reviews.author: ME

customer_reviews.title: Good price & good product
customer_reviews.text: Just planted my tomatoes yesterday, but so far these seem to be good quality. Nice thick material. I usually use the Walmart Non-Woven Polypropylene reusable shopping bags and these are a much thicker felt material. I still prefer the Walmart bags but wanted a different color than the blue they offer. I have been warned in the past to not purchase grow bags with stitching, but these seem like they might hold up a few seasons.
customer_reviews.author: BillButtLicker

customer_reviews.title: Lousy bags, buy another brand.
customer_reviews.text: Way too small and flimsy. I have 5 gallon grow bags from a different company. I ordered These because I wanted slightly bigger than the 5 gallon, but not so big as 10 gallon. These 7gallon are the same size as my 5 gallon, if not a litter under. These are also 1/2 the thickness of the other bags I have. Price per gallon, these are more expensive than the other brand.
customer_reviews.author: Rose Campbell

customer_reviews.title: NOTHING stayed alive
customer_reviews.text: NOTHING, but NOTHING grew nor stayed alive in these things, from sweet potatoes to cabbage, to blueberries, to flowers.... waste of money
customer_reviews.author: alf

customer_reviews.title: Great for root veggies and small spaces.
customer_reviews.text: Background: I’m a beginning veggie gardener and am using containers. Pros: portable, fold down when done, reusable, space saving shape, perfect depth for root vegetables, no weeding, circulation, price, perfect size for 1-3 larger root veggies or 3-5 smaller ones, space for healthy roots, slightly more protection from pests Cons: not beautiful- they are plain bags Bottom line: The bags have been reliable and easy to use across the board. I will repurchase for next Spring . Highly recommended.
customer_reviews.author: RedheadwalkingTop Contributor: Makeup

customer_reviews.title: Best cat toy ever! Also good back up for plants.
customer_reviews.text: I’ve had a pack of these spare this summer and they’ve saved me twice. Darn plastic pots a year or less old were cracking and falling all over the place. Having a pack of bags tucked away gave me a great quick back up to toss my plants into. They may not be the prettiest but it blends in when the flowers are happy and spilling over the edges. Side note. My cats LOVE these things. They play in out and all around them when one is left on the floor. I had to save a clean one indoors for them.
customer_reviews.author: Offsetanteater

customer_reviews.title: These are excellent bags
customer_reviews.text: I’m using these bags primarily to create highly acidic environments for my Blueberry bushes. The filled bags are heavy, yet the handles are strong enough that I can pick the bags up and move them around my yard. They seem like they’ll last for a long time. The bags so impressed me that after I transplanted my first few bushes that I promptly ordered more bags.
customer_reviews.author: Eric B. Simms

customer_reviews.title: I really wanted to like these.
customer_reviews.text: I bought a much larger, 5 foot planter, similar to this. It was fantastic, but I decided I wanted to separate some vegetables and these looked like the perfect solution. Well, the problem is, that water flows out of every inch of this planter. The larger one didn't leak on the sides. As a result, my plants just didn't get enough water here in Houston. I even ran separate hoses to each pot and had the sprinkler set to water them daily. Nope. they dry out way too quickly. I wish I could return these.
customer_reviews.author: Robbey

customer_reviews.title: Not quite what I expected
customer_reviews.text: I've purchased other grow bags and these seem to be a bit lighter weight, so probably less durable. My biggest issues are the size, both the height and the height to width ratio. They aren't anywhere near 10 actual gallons. Maybe the plant world uses some alternative non-real world measure. Bought these because the 5 gallon bags I have aren't big enough. For this volume, I would think most plants want more depth for the roots, less width. Picking up a filled bag shifts/cracks the soil and disrupts the plant, as the bag sags in the middle when lifted by the handles. My recommendation, if you will be needing to move these once established, look for a different product.
customer_reviews.author: A-Han The HR King

customer_reviews.title: 3rd Year Using, still buying
customer_reviews.text: I grow in bags on my patio and my garden which has lots of slope. I’ve used 20-50gal bags. Many are on their 3rd season, a few have lost handles or wore a hole in the bottom (rare). I don’t always like the proportions. I put 2 tomatoes in a 20 gal bag and they have trouble staying upright. Largest bags are too tall for me, so I fold down the sides. 30 gal seem good for tomatoes, 1-2 cages and some companion plants. Using bags I don’t have to worry about soil rotation as much.
customer_reviews.author: OZ

customer_reviews.title: I filled em up to the top and lifted it up and nothing ripped...
customer_reviews.text: Incredible product, I bought the 25 gallon one and filled it up, nothing ripped. Didn't even need the 25 gallon ones, have 10/7 gallon ones, but got it just cause of the price no joke, and glad i did, i now compost in 2 of em, and use the other 3 to hold soil and grow w/e i throw in em. Mostly cucumbers, suckers can hold about 6-9 cucumbers depending on the variety and none of the plants are worse off for it.
customer_reviews.author: Anon.

customer_reviews.title: 5 for 10 is always a sweet deal. my 6 year old made 1 a hat #kids 😂😂
customer_reviews.text: The material does not feel cheap the design is nice, the handles help a ton and I think that I paid a reasonable amount for this product, 1 thing for sure they look excellent in my 48x24x60 coolgrows grow tent, I could easily do 3 nice sized plants with these bags, I'll definitely be ordering more bags but next time they'll be bigger.
customer_reviews.author: Jacques Wise

customer_reviews.title: WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN ALL MY LIFE????
customer_reviews.text: I love these pots/bags. Gardening cannot be easier than with these bags. Remember the back-breaking tilling and de-weeding? All gone! You simply add potting soil and your seeds or seedlings and you have a garden. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THESE GROW BAGS. Even though I have an acre of land, these bags are the way to go. The 7 gallon size is perfect for what I planted (peppers, cucumbers, and tomatoes). I just planted them 2 weeks ago, but they are all strong plants and are growing nicely.
customer_reviews.author: PAULETTE'S H.

customer_reviews.title: Love these!
customer_reviews.text: These (the 7 Gallon ones) are nice BIG bags! I used them to re-pot three very small trees that were outgrowing their smaller pots. The bags themselves are thick and sturdy, based on experience w/ similar bags I'd expect them to last at least a few years if not longer without issue. So far all three trees are doing quite well in their new grow bags, and they're big enough I shouldn't have to re-pot them again before it's time for them to be transplanted outside next spring. Also, although they're definitely at the upper limits of what I care to be carrying around by myself when full, the handles make them manageable if/when they need to be moved.
customer_reviews.author: Teresa

customer_reviews.title: I am not disappointed. The quality feels and looks quite strong and ...
customer_reviews.text: I am not disappointed. The quality feels and looks quite strong and durable. I look forward to using them. I have been using their 1 gallon bags and they are quite sturdy and allow the plants to "breathe" so I expect I will not have any of them experience root rot. Looking forward to using these for tomatoes and sweet bell peppers.
customer_reviews.author: FrugalW

customer_reviews.title: Total disaster
customer_reviews.text: Purchased these figuring it would be a more earth friendly change that benefits my plants it ended it a mess . A little bit of rain and they burst throwing dirt all over. And ruined all of my plants
customer_reviews.author: Michele Palermo

customer_reviews.title: Fantastic for potatoes !  Actually great for any plants.
customer_reviews.text: Can’t comment on durability. My first season trying them. They’re great for potatoes. You can adjust the depth easily. I start the new potatoes in about 6 inches of good potting soil and just add soil as they grow leaving just the tops above ground. They’re perfect because it’s 3 feet tall. It’s much easier than mounding dirt around them while in the ground. Saves space also. Have tripled my vegetable garden in the limited space I have.
customer_reviews.author: J. Jansen

customer_reviews.title: These bags are to small for  tomatoes
customer_reviews.text: I ordered these bags for tomatoes. When I got them, they didn't look like they were 7 gallons. They looked more like 3 gallons, I have a three gallon black plastic bucket that looked much bigger. I planted them anyway with tomatoes and peppers. The tomatoes and peppers grew very well in these, but the leaves on the taller tomatoes , would shrivel and turn brown because there was just not enough soil to retain enough water. Next year I will try 10 gallons for tomatoes. I will say that everything I have planted in grow bags - the largest I ordered was 15 gallons - has grown very well.
customer_reviews.author: Dixie Gainer

customer_reviews.title: 30 gallon
customer_reviews.text: They run just a bit smaller than described but still very sturdy and more than enough room for root growth. I know liquid and dry measurements vary slightly and the size I ordered, 30 gallon, measured out to 27 dry gallons. I'd say that is close enough to satisfy. Besides there isn't really a way to precisely measure the shift and stretch of the bags fabric if filled with water as it would all just seep out as it was being filled.
customer_reviews.author: shannon melgar

customer_reviews.title: fine garden pots
customer_reviews.text: Arrvd on time & well pkd. These will hold my entire potato crop. Can't plant them in the same spot as last season as potatoes, tomatoes a& peppers are all in the belladona family & must be roated between garden areas every year to prevent disease.
customer_reviews.author: Bonnie J. Howell

customer_reviews.title: Nicely made and plants thrive in them!
customer_reviews.text: I am impressed with how well made these grow bags are. I have made them myself before using weed tarp/fabric but those you have to be very careful with tears and they are hard to move. These bags are very sturdy and the material is pretty heavy duty. The plants I have planted in them are thriving! I have been so impressed, I ordered another set and the plants in those are already sprouted and growing quickly. I am considering buying a third set!
customer_reviews.author: DE2695

customer_reviews.title: I used a little fertilizer about every six weeks and I now have a great crop of tomatoes and peppers
customer_reviews.text: I grew my tomatoes and peppers in these this summer using Miracle Go potting mix (without wetting agents). I used a little fertilizer about every six weeks and I now have a great crop of tomatoes and peppers. The only setback is they go dry very easily. You have to check every day and make sure the mix isn't dry. Keep it moist. If you don't, your tomatoes might develop blossom end rot.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Solid grow bag with good durability
customer_reviews.text: I've been using these to grow my chilis. Every plant that I moved to one of these ended up flowering and growing fruit. Not very cheap but definitely cheaper than the grow bags that are available at local nurseries or chain gardening centers. Pros: - Sturdy - Durable (I've been using these for over a year now both indoors and outdoors - Better price than trying to buy individually in local stores - Handles are nice Cons: - Because the fabric is so sturdy, you have to really pack in the dirt/soil so that there are no air-gaps.
customer_reviews.author: Debounce

customer_reviews.title: Handy bags for growing veggies like potatoes
customer_reviews.text: These bags are larger than my previous purchase as they are 5 gallons. I used 2 gallon ones last year and they were fine but because of the drought I had to water twice a day and although they grew potatoes OK, I thought the larger bags would give the potatoes more space. We are having the opposite of drought this year but one good thing about these bags is they drain excess moisture well. Time will tell how well my crop will be this year. I have these on my back deck and place them on plastic to protect the decking. These are easy to relocated because of the handles.
customer_reviews.author: Lulu43

customer_reviews.title: Water directly into bags at roots!!!
customer_reviews.text: I like the idea. Only problem is you HAVE to water your plants DIRECTLY on the roots right into the bags. If you water from top, you will dry out your plants. That happened to me last year, tomatoes were wilting and growing roots above the soil desperately searching for water, despite the fact that I put the sprinkler on them everyday. I put up screens and all sorts of nonsense because I thought they were getting too much sun. Figured it out after I picked them up to move them and they were extremely light. Giving them another try this year.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: They didn’t work as well as a normal garden pot.
customer_reviews.text: Items are exactly as described, I got them because I had heard so many great things about using grow bags, but just not at all impressed with the results. Everything I grew in them was stunted and produced very little yield. I do not think this is the fault of the manufacturer, just that high heat environment may not be the best to use these in. Used the same soil as my garden with vastly different results.
customer_reviews.author: Joseph A.

customer_reviews.title: They looked very sturdy but I ordered 7 Gallon Grow Bags because I ...
customer_reviews.text: They looked very sturdy but I ordered 7 Gallon Grow Bags because I wanted to plant my Watermelon in them. So I read that I needed atleast a 5+ gallon grow bags so I decided to get the 7 Gallon. When I got them I thought they sent me wrong ones but package stated 7 Gallons. Very Small compare to other Grow Bags I had ordered before. They are not wide and I don't see how they can possible be 7 Gallons. Either way, I will see how my watermelon will do in these containers.
customer_reviews.author: Aleyda

customer_reviews.title: Great value. We have lots of these with saplings, herbs, and vegetables in them.
customer_reviews.text: These are a great value for the price. I have about thirty fruit trees in grow bags in my front courtyard. I buy fruit trees that I want whenever I see them and put them in temporary grow bags until it is the right time of year to put them in the ground. These grow bags are perfect for any tree seedling or sapling that you want to keep in a grow bag for a year or two. These grow bags are also perfect for seasonal vegetables. We perpetually have about a dozen of these with herbs in them.
customer_reviews.author: gamgam

customer_reviews.title: 3 gallon fabric pot 5 pack was exactly what I expected.
customer_reviews.text: Bought the 7 gallon set last year (in use again already this year). These are good draining, sturdy fabric pots, think heavy landscape type fabric. Handles seem very secure even on he 7 gal pots from last year. It seems to me, with fabric pots, drainage is good but you don't want it to sit in a puddle. I built several inexpensive "coasters" last year and they're great for keeping the 7 gals up an inch or two for draining and circulation. Good luck with that green thumb!
customer_reviews.author: Brian Carroll

customer_reviews.title: Awesome and Convenient
customer_reviews.text: I was apprehensive about how these bags might work. We live in town with limited space and I wanted to try something new so I threw a few potatoes in these bags, not expecting too much, and I can't believe how they grew! We had plants 4 feet tall and they were earlier than usual for northern Minnesota. I dumped a bag and out came a ton of beautiful pristine potatoes! The best part is the bags are still in fantastic shape. They look like I'll be able to use them for several gardening seasons.
customer_reviews.author: Missycoo

customer_reviews.title: Good
customer_reviews.text: Planted a bunch of veggies in these. They seem fine so far. Happy to be able to have a convenient garden without having to mess with the yard. These are easy to manage and growing everything vertically saves space. I bought the 20gallon plus 10 and 7 gallon in other brands. So far I have found that my vegetable plants really do not get large enough in anything less than the 20 gallon maybe 15 gallon at the least. So if you are trying to plant veggies use the larger ones unless you have some super plant food or an excellent green thumb.
customer_reviews.author: Joanna

customer_reviews.title: Great for Peppers
customer_reviews.text: I have been growing superhot peppers in grow bags for a few years. They seem to do very well in the growbag versus a plastic pot of the same size. I'm certain this is due to oxygen reaching the roots and the improved drainage. If you live in an hot summer climate, you'll eventually need to water frequently as the peppers will become root bound in the bag. Even when they reach this stage, I've gotten exceptional yields from such plants. My only complaint is that I wish the bags would hold up a little better over multiple seasons, but at the price this is hardly a deal-breaker.
customer_reviews.author: Stephen Peele

customer_reviews.title: Very Nice Grow Pots! 247Garden Customer Service is excellent.
customer_reviews.text: I ordered the 1 Gallon pots and the quality is excellent. These will last me a few years for sure (inside grow). I have interacted with 247Garden via email asking questions and was promptly replied with a return email. 247Garden has very good products and customer service is top tier.
customer_reviews.author: Tony

customer_reviews.title: Such a great product and idea
customer_reviews.text: Such a great product and idea that I don't understand why more people don't use them in their indoor gardens. I had some rather large pepper and ghost pepper plants for my hotsauce business and the thrived in these airpots! When I pulled the soil out the roots weren't root bound and the soil was one sold cylinder of soil.
customer_reviews.author: Hekkenschütze

customer_reviews.title: Happy, healthy trees in forever pots.
customer_reviews.text: We live in an apartment still. With long hopes of getting the home of our dreams I prematurely bought trees. A few months before the move we repotted our trees in these pots. Weighing a couple two or three hundred pounds each after all the soil and mulch and water it took two grown men to move them. Using the handles and each of us with a hand under to move them into the uhaul the pots really proved their sturdiness. Our trees are very happy in these pots greener and full of life. I love having peace of mind that they never have to be repotted and are not in danger of being over watered.
customer_reviews.author: Cl84

customer_reviews.title: Well-made bags
customer_reviews.text: Love the sturdy construction of these bags. We are using them for potatoes and they are working well so far. The handles are attached well so they should hold up if we need to move the bags when full. We live in a coastal climate and the bags drain well after it rains so the roots of the plants can breathe better than the plastic nursery pots we used before. We put them on boards suspended over concrete blocks to keep them off the ground. This makes them easier to reach as well as avoiding any roots going into the ground under the bags.
customer_reviews.author: D. Henley

customer_reviews.title: 3 Years and Still Growing
customer_reviews.text: Bought about 20 of these in 2016! Have torn a couple but should get another season for sure. These stay in my garden so that's 3 years of heavy duty use. I even plant some clover and peas over the winter in them for green manure. I use these mainly for peppers and cherry tomatoes but did grow some Cherokee purples and they did great. My 5 gallon plastic buckets lasted about 2 years before the sun did them in and with the plastic problems around the world these may be an alternative. Yes, these are woven polyester but so are your pants and they will decompose in the compost. Nothing last forever and one day we all get recycled!
customer_reviews.author: Michael J. Smith

customer_reviews.title: Great price for containers
customer_reviews.text: Great price for containers! work well for growing vegetables, herbs, strawberries, and tomatoes! The downside, as they are fabric containers, they are great for air pruning roots, however being only 7 gallon capacity, the soil dries out very quickly. I would recommend only growing plants in these that like dry climates and very well drained soil conditions. Lettuce is probably not a good choice to plant in these unless you want to be watering all the time.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Works great!
customer_reviews.text: I just learned about these fabric growing containers and am so happy I purchased them. They're less expensive that clay or plastic containers, and they're lightweight, even when filled with soil. Easy to move with the handles. I grew herbs and tomatoes in mine this year and they were wonderful. Looks like I'll be able to reuse them next year. Great purchase.
customer_reviews.author: ButterYum

customer_reviews.title: Great temporary potting alternative. Strong, light weight, and pack down nicely in between uses.
customer_reviews.text: They are working like a charm. Had to move a bunch of plants temporarily because of having large trees removed. These were an easy solution to place my plants for the interim. They held up nicely, allowed good drainage, and are good to go for the next time I need to move a plant. Now they are serving as a second layer for my potted plants for the winter. I would purchase again.
customer_reviews.author: Danielle

customer_reviews.title: They work great
customer_reviews.text: These pots work awesome. Our tomato’s and Basile are twice the size of the stuff we have in the ground! Will definitely be using them again. The bags are very durable.
customer_reviews.author: Brad S.

customer_reviews.title: Movable!
customer_reviews.text: They have lasted the whole growing season. They are a little bulky with the plants in them but I’m still able to move them around. I used them for vegetable plants we had a dry summer so I had to do a lot of watering. I probably won’t use them for that again next year. They did work for my herbs on the deck, very convenient!
customer_reviews.author: Penny W.

customer_reviews.title: Don't use indoors
customer_reviews.text: I didn't think this through when I put plant starts indoors in these grow bags. At first there was no problem, but as the soil dried out, it became repellent to the water and streamed right out the sides all over my window sill and down the wall. They are well made of a sturdy tyveck type material that will probably last a few seasons. Personally, I think they are too small for my use, they dry out fast.
customer_reviews.author: Angeles E Oakes

customer_reviews.title: Not a good substitute for actual containers
customer_reviews.text: I grew tomatoes and flowers in these last year. It was the worst growing year EVER for me. Tomatoes dried out far too much between daily waterings and they tipped over constantly. My dad had purchased a bunch of these grow bags around the same time I did and he experienced the same issues. Never again!
customer_reviews.author: Ellen Kling

customer_reviews.title: durable product
customer_reviews.text: Grew sweet potatoes in them last year and it turned out pretty well. I forgot to bring them in from the garden so they were out all winter but when I found them the other day they were still in just as good of shape as when I bought them. They are a high quality product that I'm sure to get at least 5 years of use out of possibly more especially if they survived an Indiana winter.
customer_reviews.author: mrtdrew

customer_reviews.title: Best way to grow tomatoes and other veg
customer_reviews.text: This is my second year growing from these types of containers. I love them for growing vegetables and strawberries. They are easy to move with handles to drag across my deck for best position. This was especially handy when we had an unexpected snow storm here in Denver. There is no pooling of water as the material helps with drainage. I have successful grown tomatoes, strawberries, squash, cucumbers, peppers and zucchinis. Tomato or bean trellis cages fit perfectly. I will be buy more.
customer_reviews.author: Jodie Marie Shaw

customer_reviews.title: Needs to water daily.
customer_reviews.text: Needs to water daily. And you will never be sure that the water flows through evenly. Forget going on trips for more than two days.
customer_reviews.author: Big Canoe

customer_reviews.title: Great for moving plants or having soft pots for summer gardens
customer_reviews.text: I have grown tomatoes and other veggies in these during the summer months. I have also used these to transport plants to different houses. They're lightweight, hold a lot of soil, the handles are long enough and convenient, and they have lasted several seasons. I really like being able to fold them up small and store them easily when not in use. They also drain exceptionally well.
customer_reviews.author: always curious

customer_reviews.title: Still getting the hang of these. I purchased them ...
customer_reviews.text: Still getting the hang of these. I purchased them because I accidentally drown one of my plants and it never recovered. These drain as soon as the soil is saturated and the roots get plenty of air. The down side is now I have to water every other day.
customer_reviews.author: Pete from Mass

customer_reviews.title: Way too expensive
customer_reviews.text: BUYER BEWARE!! I’ve been buying these for over a year now they aren’t any where as good as the smart pots and much cheaper made. But I’ve been buying these for over a year and when the price was below 10$ for a 5 pack they were great. Then the price went up about 2$ To $10.95 which I was alright with because I was comfortable with product now that these have gone up 5$ a 5 pack since first started buying. Now I will NOT pay the $12.95 a pack when I can go and get the smart pot for the SAME price. But smart pots are a much better quality!!
customer_reviews.author: Alex Barone

customer_reviews.title: Hard to transplant
customer_reviews.text: So I like this concept but the roots grab onto felt and it’s hard to transplant. That’s really it. And I’m not so sure about the “10” gal volume. More like 7 maybe. A 5 gal bucket seems similar in volume? Not sure how they measure that.
customer_reviews.author: Babsly

customer_reviews.title: Using them for 3rd year!
customer_reviews.text: Living in a rental we couldn't dig up the yard to plant a vegetable garden so we purchased these grow bags in the spring of 2018 and have zero regrets! Have used them for the past two summers and plan to use the again this year. Have grown tomatoes, squash, eggplant, peppers, and melons in the bags and haven't had any issues. The bags do dry out quicker than other potting options so you'll need to remember to water regularly.
customer_reviews.author: RachelE

customer_reviews.title: These have lasted well
customer_reviews.text: I have used these for 4 seasons now going into the 5th season and they are still solid. I just refilled them and lifted them and nothing is tearing or loose. I figured the bottoms would fall out after a couple years but still strong. I like i can move them out of the way in Winter. I do water a bit more since they are black and above ground but they don't take much extra water. This year will be melons but work well for potatoes and just dump the bags out to harvest. i have both 15 and 25 gallon versions both lasting well.
customer_reviews.author: Tara Anderson

product_meta.title: 247Garden 5-Pack 7 Gallon Grow Bags/Aeration Fabric Pots w/Handles (Black)
product_meta.description: Size:7-Gallon| Color:Black247Garden's 7-Gallon Aeration Fabric Pots combine the ease of use of a traditional nursery pot with the benefit of a breathable container. Keep the roots of your favorite plants cooler with more room to grow by planting in a breathable 247Garden Aeration Fabric Pot today! Made with 100% non-woven 260g landscape fabric, BPA-free and environmental-friendly felt. Sold in pack of 5. Key Benefits of 247Garden Aeration Containers: Stronger, healthier plants from start to finish. Improved overall root structure, producing more root tips. Elimination of root circling in pots Decreased risk of transplant shock. Better use of water and nutrients. Quicker growing time with bigger yields. With a 7-gallon aeration fabric pot, you can grow big tomato plants with some good space left for garlic and more!
feature_bullets: 247Garden Aeration Fabric Pots allow roots to breathe and grow healthier, boosts plant growth and yields.
Decreased risk of transplant shock, creates improved overall root structure.
Keeps plant warmer in winter and cooler in the summer.
Prevents roots from circling. Decreased risk of transplant shock.

specifications.Customer Reviews: 4.6 out of 5 stars4,694 ratings4.6 out of 5 stars
